pathology.primary: thick cisternal clot with intraventricular hemorrhage
pathology.primaryDiagnosis: thick cisternal clot with intraventricular hemorrhage

imaging: CTA if elevated TCD velocities (>120 cm/s MCA)
DSA at 6 months if incompletely treated
medications: DVT prophylaxis (SCDs, consider heparin after securing aneurysm)
monitoring: Neuro checks q1h x 48h, then q2h
Watch for delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI) POD 4-14

procedures.name: Digital Subtraction Angiography with Endovascular Coiling of ACOM Aneurysm

found.context:
ADMISSION:

1. Lisinopril 20mg PO daily
2. Atorvastatin 40mg PO daily
3. Metformin 1000mg PO BID
4. Aspirin 81mg PO daily (HELD on admission)

ALLERGIES:

Penicillin (rash)

SOCIAL HISTORY:
- Retired account

findings: Diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage in basal cisterns, sylvian fissures, and interhemispheric fissure
Fisher Grade 4 (thick cisternal clot with intraventricular hemorrhage)
Mild hydrocephalus with temporal horn dilation
8mm saccular aneurysm of anterior communicating artery (ACOM)

_suggestions.reason: Hunt-Hess grade is critical for SAH prognosis and treatment planning
_suggestions.whereToFind: Look for: "Hunt-Hess", "H&H", "HH grade" in admission notes, neurosurgery consult, or imaging reports
_suggestions.clinicalSignificance: Predicts mortality: Grade 1-2 (10-20%), Grade 3 (30-40%), Grade 4-5 (60-80%). Guides ICU level of care.

_suggestions.reason: Fisher grade predicts vasospasm risk - essential for monitoring plan
_suggestions.whereToFind: Look for: "Fisher", "Modified Fisher", "mFisher" in CT head reports or neurosurgery notes
_suggestions.clinicalSignificance: Grade 3 has 60-70% vasospasm risk. Determines TCD monitoring frequency and nimodipine duration.

_suggestions.reason: GCS is fundamental for neurological assessment
_suggestions.whereToFind: Look for: "GCS", "Glasgow Coma Scale", "E_V_M_" in any clinical note
_suggestions.clinicalSignificance: GCS tracks neurological status. Decline ‚â•2 points requires immediate imaging.

_suggestions.reason: Aneurysm location affects treatment approach and follow-up
_suggestions.whereToFind: Look for: "PCOM", "ACOM", "MCA", "basilar" in CTA/angiogram reports or operative notes
_suggestions.clinicalSignificance: Location determines surgical vs endovascular approach and recurrence risk.

_suggestions.reason: Aneurysm size affects rupture risk and treatment complexity
_suggestions.whereToFind: Look for: size in mm in CTA/angiogram reports (e.g., "5mm aneurysm")
_suggestions.clinicalSignificance: Size >7mm = higher rupture risk. Larger aneurysms may require complex treatment.

_suggestions.reason: Nimodipine is standard of care for SAH - should be documented
_suggestions.whereToFind: Look for: "nimodipine", "Nimotop", "60mg q4h" in medication list
_suggestions.clinicalSignificance: Nimodipine reduces poor outcomes by 40%. Given for 21 days post-SAH.

_suggestions.reason: Functional status (mRS or KPS) documents baseline and outcome
_suggestions.whereToFind: Look for: "mRS", "Rankin", "KPS", "Karnofsky" or infer from discharge destination and support level
_suggestions.clinicalSignificance: mRS 0-2 = good outcome, 3-5 = poor outcome. Guides discharge planning.

events.description: Patient admitted directly to Neuro ICU. Started on nimodipine 60mg PO q4h for vasospasm prophylaxis. External ventricular drain (EVD) placed at bedside by Dr. Johnson at 18:00 for hydrocephalus management. Opening pressure 28 cm H2O. Drain set to 15 cm H2O above tragus, draining clear CSF. Levetiracetam 500mg IV BID started for seizure prophylaxis. Blood pressure goal 140-160 systolic. Strict bed rest with head of bed at 30 degrees.
- Diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage in basal cisterns, sylvian fissures, and interhemispheric fissure

Excellent. Patient had successful treatment of ruptured ACOM aneurysm with complete occlusion. Despite symptomatic vasospasm on Day 6, patient recovered completely without infarction. Discharged with mRS 0 (no symptoms) and KPS 100 (normal function). Risk of rebleeding is now <1% with complete aneurysm occlusion. Will require long-term follow-up to monitor for aneurysm recurrence and delayed complications.

hospitalCourse.summary: Day 1 (09/15/2024): Patient admitted directly to Neuro ICU. Started on nimodipine 60mg PO q4h for vasospasm prophylaxis. External ventricular drain (EVD) placed at bedside by Dr. Johnson at 18:00 for hydrocephalus management. Opening pressure 28 cm H2O. Drain set to 15 cm H2O above tragus, draining clear CSF. Levetiracetam 500mg IV BID started for seizure prophylaxis. Blood pressure goal 140-160 systolic. Strict bed rest with head of bed at 30 degrees. Day 2 (09/16/2024): Patient underwent digital subtraction angiography (DSA) with endovascular coiling of ACOM aneurysm by Dr. Michael Chen (Interventional Neuroradiology) at 09:00. Procedure time: 3 hours 15 minutes. Complete occlusion achieved (Raymond-Roy Class 1). No procedural complications. Post-procedure exam: Neurologically intact, GCS 15. Continued on nimodipine and levetiracetam. EVD draining well, ICP 8-12 mmHg.
